body: Hm...it's failing with the same error...this is weird. Investigating further...
Rebased and submitted a new patch to trigger a new Travis CI build.

@goelrajat you might have to rebase your commit on latest master to get Travis builds to pass. Just pushed a build fix a few minutes ago. I'll leave it to @smolnar82 and @moresandeep to review

Thanks @risdenk for the comments. I have refactored the code with a Base test class. I had a quick look at how to implement Junit Parameterized test. In my case, I need to parameterize setting up of Gateway config role and starting of Gateway Server which would be done repeatedly for both the test cases so not much performance gain in terms of test case execution. Please check.

@risdenk  Rebase has no impact:
bash-3.2$ git pull origin master
From https://github.com/goelrajat/knox
 * branch                master     -> FETCH_HEAD
Already up to date.
bash-3.2$ git rebase master
Current branch KNOX-1997 is up to date.
bash-3.2$
> https://github.com/goelrajat/knox Your master is behind `apache/knox` by 21 commits: First, you need to pull changes from `apache/master` to your master then you can rebase.
@smolnar82 Done. Thanks

One more thing: since you added a new configuration in `gateway-site.xml` it should be documented (even if it's optional). Could you please open another JIRA to modify the user guide?
Thanks!

Nope; works for me now!
There is a bug in my service.xml, will upload a new patch.
@moresandeep does this need to touch the atlas api service definition as well?
I don't think this needs to touch the atlas api, atlas api service appears to be exclusively used for APIs unlike the case with Ranger Service defs.
Thanks @shanyu didn't see you pushed a change. I'll take a look at this tomorrow and see if Travis is happy.

@sharad-oss looks like the jdk11 Travis failure might be real as well:

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-compiler-plugin:3.8.1:compile (default-compile) on project gateway-provider-security-aws: Fatal error compiling: java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError: com.sun.tools.javac.code.TypeTags -> [Help 1]
```
@risdenk I wasn't aware Knox was being built on JDK-11 too. My current tests were all done using JDK-8. I will invest some time to build with JDK-11.
@moresandeep @risdenk @pzampino Could you please review my changes? Thanks!

@lmccay4 so I think a lot of the concern from the comments come from dealing with strings directly. This ends up requiring a lot of type specific methods. Is there a reason that strings are being passed around and filtered on directly instead of the underlying datatype?

> @lmccay4 so I think a lot of the concern from the comments come from dealing with strings directly. This ends up requiring a lot of type specific methods. Is there a reason that strings are being passed around and filtered on directly instead of the underlying datatype?

The underlying data type is String for all of the values in the table.

From my comment on JIRA KNOX-2020:

@sharad-oss - this looks interesting!
I'd actually like to see a one-pager type doc that describes the usecases, the design and security considerations. Please attach it to the JIRA itself.
One thing that I am concerned about is the inclusion of sensitive credentials in the JWT based cookie.
The cookie from KnoxSSO is intended for browsers and generally represents the authenticated user but doesn't include credentials. It is essentially in clear text since the JWT is merely base64 encoded. This is not sufficient protection for credentials that can be used outside of the scope of Knox itself.
In terms of usecases, I'd like to understand the full flow including how/where the credentials are actually used and what consumer will be provided in Knox for the credentials.
@lmccay sure will work on the one pager doc soon, and update the JIRA.
In regards to the failed check, it builds fine on my machine, unsure why it's failing on here but it doesn't seem to be from my change.

Travis build failed due to failure in test case WebsocketServerInitiatedMessageTest, however the same test case is passing on my local setup. I tried multiple times but it works on my side.

I believe this PR should be closed and unmerged and a new one should be created with the new code.

Most likely going to want to rebase this change on top of PR #157

Test case changes have been done. Please check and merge.
Test case changes have been done. Please check and merge.
LGTM +1

> @risdenk my responses don't seem to showing up for whatever reason.

@lmccay4 if you are in "review mode" - you need to make sure you submit the comments otherwise they just sit in draft basically.

@risdenk Addressed your feedback. I am seeing some test failures but they don't seem related to my changes.

I am also working on a one pager as requested by @lmccay.
@moresandeep Please check and merge this one as well.
@pzampino could you possible take a look? You appear to have implemented the check in the first place in KNOX-1341. Thanks
Change looks good to me. Limited to only the 3 cookies that Knox will check anyway. Waiting on @pzampino to review as well
@lmccay @lmccay4 @risdenk @moresandeep @pzampino Could any of you review my changes, please! Thanks!
@risdenk Travis CI build failure is unrelated; could you please re-trigger the job? Thanks!
Another idea: once you added `long` support you may consider `Date` or `Timestamp` columns using `getTime()`. What do you think?

> Another idea: once you added `long` support you may consider `Date` or `Timestamp` columns using `getTime()`. What do you think?

@smolnar82 I could see this being useful with finding `mode,` but not quite sure how the rest of the methods here would lend themselves to a date/timestamp. `Max` and `min` could also be useful but I would think that would be more of `sort` thing where you would want the table itself displayed in order with max/min on respective ends of the table. Are there any specific use cases you had in mind? This might be going over my head. Filing a separate JIRA might be a good idea for this.

> > Another idea: once you added `long` support you may consider `Date` or `Timestamp` columns using `getTime()`. What do you think?
> 
> @smolnar82 I could see this being useful with finding `mode,` but not quite sure how the rest of the methods here would lend themselves to a date/timestamp. `Max` and `min` could also be useful but I would think that would be more of `sort` thing where you would want the table itself displayed in order with max/min on respective ends of the table. Are there any specific use cases you had in mind? This might be going over my head. Filing a separate JIRA might be a good idea for this.

I believe selecting the `min` and `max` date/timestamp is very useful and frequently used in applications dealing with those data types (e.g. give me the last time John logged in). It's true that the same can be achieved with sorting (ascending/descending) and selecting the first element from the result. I'll create a new JIRA.
@lmccay4 / @lmccay would be good to review as well.
Ignore latest patch, I messed it up.
Latest push should find all reviews addressed and free of merge conflicts, hopefully.
@moresandeep Can you please merge this PR? I want to raise another PR for KNOX-2004 and its changes are dependent on this PR.

> @moresandeep Can you please merge this PR? I want to raise another PR for KNOX-2004 and its changes are dependent on this PR.

@goelrajat I will get to it probably mid next week, since this is pretty involved and touches a bunch of things I would like to test it thoroughly.
@risdenk New patch is available for review
@risdenk @lmccay @moresandeep @pzampino Can any of you please review my changes? (sorry for the long description, but I believe that is useful information to share)
@risdenk Could you please review this one? Thanks!
Doing some more manual tests before merging this.
All tests passed locally. Docker Hub is down causing this failure.
@risdenk I did a minor refactor to have the `KnoxShellTable` generate its own ID instead of setting it by the filter/builder. Please review. Thanks!
@smolnar82 - Since you were involved in the review of previous revisions of this patch can you take a look and make sure your concerns have been resolved or have follow up JIRAs?
Reopened to trigger a new Travis CI build (the previous error was unrelated).
Created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KNOX-2062 to address `RemoteConfigurationMonitorTest` issues in Travis CI.

@risdenk - I addressed all of your above-comments:
- removed the Guava dependency (created a new utility class to determine if a Collection is sorted)
- removed the `commons-lang3` dependency by simply implementing the `toString` method with a `StringBuilder`
- synchronized  and reduced visibility of marshaller/unmarshaller access
- changed the responses in the new API
  - if successfully processed the `Location` header will indicate the created/updated resource location
  - if failed the error we return starts with a constant

> The other thing we need to check is if the new module is included in the release pom and makes it into the final release tar.gz/src

It is included and the final release contains the binary (in .zip and tar.gz files) as well as the source.
I always test with fully released binaries when doing E2E tests.
@lmccay / @moresandeep Can any of you please review my changes? Thanks!
@risdenk - can this be merged?

@lmccay, @moresandeep (@risdenk)
I need this to be merged so that I can submit the UI part.

> Nice work, @smolnar82!
> I like the paging that you added.
> Also, not having to do the restart and topology touch to get rewrite rule changes to take effect is HUGE!

Thanks!

> I did see an exception thrown on update of a service definition related to URI not being a file schema or something like that.

There was a nasty bug in `org.apache.knox.gateway.service.admin.TopologiesResource` which I fixed in a [separate commit in this PR](https://github.com/apache/knox/pull/169/commits/1acb624838a5f81a5d65538a9e44bff16bf4f280).
 
> I'd suggest a follow up JIRA for adding new Service Definition either from scratch with a template to get started or at least a copy from existing like we have for Topologies.

See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KNOX-2068
@moresandeep any update here?
Still underwater, hoping to find some time by the end of this week.

I have test Spark, Hive and is ok, other application types is not tested yet.
Ping @smolnar82 as well since you were asking about this Jira

Hmm. It looks like the check at https://api.travis-ci.org/v3/job/607855611/log.txt failed, but the logs suggest that it may be running plugins that aren't thread safe. Assuming that this is a threading issue, is there any way to rerun the tests, possibly without parallelism?

The error was 

```
[ERROR] Failures: 
[ERROR]   GatewayCorrelationIdTest.testTestService:209 
Expected: is <46>
     but: was <45>
```

Not an error I've seen before. I retriggered the JDK 11 job. We have some flaky tests related to ZK but not that test.
@lmccay Please review.
@lmccay The follow-up JIRA is created and a PR is already submitted (https://github.com/apache/knox/pull/179)

Hi Kevin, sorry for the late followup; was out yesterday. Seems like it failed on gateway-service-remoteconfig again; was it still the testTestService test? I don't have JDK 11 installed on this machine and I'd like to confirm before trying to pursue the error.
(On that note, is there any good way to check the Surefire reports/view build artifacts?)

Grasping at straws here, but looking through the test case at https://github.com/apache/knox/blob/89caa5feeed706abc8d7ce1407830ae00d97d405/gateway-test/src/test/java/org/apache/knox/gateway/GatewayCorrelationIdTest.java, is it possible that the reduced timeout might be causing the issue and that accepting HttpStatus.SC_GATEWAY_TIMEOUTs as well/raising the socketTimeout parameter somehow may fix the issue? I'm not completely sure how the test works, but with the change in this PR, all connection attempts that experience a socket timeout are automatically given a 403, whereas without the change, there would at least be an attempt to contact the failover nodes.

...then again, I suppose this wouldn't explain the successes in JDK8. It's a bit difficult to tell without looking at the reports unfortunately.

I am going to try to make time next week to test this and make sure that all the different links in the yarnui service definition still work. Want to put it through its paces since we just recently fixed a lot of the YARNUI service definition parts
